commander.name: Major-General Raymond Briggs

chief_of_staff.name: Unknown
chief_of_staff.note: Staff details not available in primary sources

M4 Sherman II.note: Primary equipment of 2nd Armoured Brigade. 2nd Armoured Brigade equipped with 92 Shermans at El Alamein opening

M3 Grant.note: Secondary equipment, mixed with Shermans in some regiments

Crusader III.note: Limited numbers for reconnaissance and close support roles

M3 Stuart.note: Reconnaissance and screening roles, 4 per armoured regiment HQ

supply_logistics.supply_status: Adequate for offensive operations. British 8th Army enjoyed substantial supply superiority over Axis forces. Main supply line from Alexandria (100km east) well-established. During 12-day battle, division fired over 200,000 rounds of 25-pounder ammunition. Water and fuel supplies prioritized for armor operations. Primary advantage: short supply lines compared to Axis forces supplied from Tripoli (1,800km west).

weather_environment.season_quarter: 1942-Q4 (October-December): Autumn transitioning to winter, optimal campaigning season

temperature_range_c.note: October-November temperatures. Daytime comfortable for operations, cool nights.

weather_environment.terrain_type: coastal plain and rocky desert (Ruweisat Ridge area). Firm ground suitable for armor operations. Limited vegetation. Qattara Depression to south (impassable) channeled operations along coast.

subordinate_units.equipment_note: Equipped with M4 Sherman II tanks (92 total) as primary equipment, with some M3 Grant tanks mixed

subordinate_units.support: 4th Royal Horse Artillery Regiment, 4th Field Squadron Royal Engineers
subordinate_units.note: Motor battalions transported in trucks and carriers. Previously 7th Armoured Division Support Group, transferred to 1st Armoured Division before El Alamein.

regiments: Divisional Anti-Tank Regiment, Royal Artillery (mixed 6-pdr and 2-pdr)
Light Anti-Aircraft Regiment, Royal Artillery (Bofors 40mm, Oerlikon 20mm)

subordinate_units.equipment: Daimler Armoured Cars, Marmon-Herrington Mk III, Universal Carriers, light tanks

squadrons: 4th Field Squadron, Royal Engineers (attached to 7th Motor Brigade)
subordinate_units.roles: Mine clearance, bridging, demolitions, field fortifications
subordinate_units.note: Mine clearance critical during El Alamein offensive through extensive Axis minefields

subordinate_units.equipment: Wireless sets (No. 19, No. 11, No. 18), line equipment, motorcycles, signals vehicles

units: Royal Army Service Corps (RASC) transport and supply companies
Royal Army Ordnance Corps (RAOC) ammunition and stores
Royal Electrical and Mechanical Engineers (REME) workshops
Royal Army Medical Corps (RAMC) field ambulances and dressing stations
subordinate_units.note: Essential logistics tail supporting armoured operations in desert conditions

tactical_doctrine.role: Primary armoured exploitation force for British Eighth Army. Breakthrough operations through Axis minefields and defensive positions. Pursuit of defeated enemy forces westward into Libya. Combined arms coordination between armour, motor infantry, and artillery.
special_capabilities: First British division equipped substantially with M4 Sherman tanks - superior firepower and protection
Experienced desert warfare formation after operations in 1941-1942
Strong artillery support with three field artillery regiments (72× 25-pounders)
Motor infantry brigade provided mobile infantry support for armour
tactical_innovations: Coordinated 'all-arms' battle groups combining tanks, infantry, artillery, engineers
Systematic breaching of minefields using engineer teams under artillery cover
Night operations during El Alamein breakthrough phase
Concentrated artillery fire missions - division contributed to 1 million+ 25-pdr rounds fired
Sherman tanks allowed direct engagement of German Panzer IIIs and IVs on more equal terms
known_issues: Tank-infantry cooperation still developing - coordination challenges
Sherman tanks, while superior to earlier Crusaders, still inferior to German Panzer IV Ausf. F2/G with long 75mm
Motor infantry vulnerable when dismounted in open desert
Logistics strain during pursuit operations as supply lines extended
Mine warfare casualties - extensive Axis minefields at El Alamein
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: Extensive water transport capacity (185 water tankers). Fuel bowsers (165) for extended operations. Sand filters on vehicles. Desert camouflage and netting. Recovery vehicles for tank breakdown/damage. Mobile workshops for field repairs. Specialized desert navigation equipment.

scenario_suitability: Second Battle of El Alamein (23 October - 4 November 1942) - opening breakthrough
Combined arms armoured division vs. Panzerarmee Afrika
special_rules: Sherman Firepower: M4 Sherman 75mm gun effective against medium German tanks
Combined Arms Doctrine: Bonus when infantry, tanks, and artillery coordinate
Desert Veterans: Experience bonus for desert terrain operations
Superior Logistics: Reduced supply penalties compared to Axis forces
Artillery Superiority: +1 to artillery fire missions due to ammunition abundance
historical_engagements: First Battle of El Alamein (July 1942) - defensive operations, formation rebuilding
Battle of Alam Halfa (August-September 1942) - defensive victory, Sherman debut

wargaming_data.opposing_forces: German-Italian Panzerarmee Afrika: 15th Panzer Division, 21st Panzer Division, 90th Light Division, Ariete Armoured Division, Littorio Armoured Division

validation.methodology: Data compiled from multiple primary and secondary sources. Tank numbers based on historical records of 1st Armoured Division receiving 92 Shermans by El Alamein opening, supplemented with Grant tanks in mixed regiments. Personnel strength calculated from British armoured division establishment (approx. 14,000-15,000 all ranks in 1942 reorganized structure). Artillery from documented three field regiments plus divisional anti-tank and anti-aircraft regiments. Motor brigade composition confirmed from multiple sources showing 2nd KRRC, 2nd Rifle Brigade, 7th Rifle Brigade. Supply and environmental data from El Alamein operational analysis and North Africa desert conditions Q4 1942.
